text: Aglaea () or Aglaïa (; Ancient Greek: Ἀγλαΐα "splendor, brilliant, shining one") is the name of several figures in Greek mythology: * Aglaia, one of the three Charites. * Aglaea, the goddess/personification of the glow of good health, and a daughter of Asclepius and Epione. Her sisters are Hygieia, Panacea, Aceso, and Iaso,Greek Lyric Anonymous, Fragments 939 (Inscription from Erythrai) (trans. Campbell)Suidas s.v. Epione (trans. Suda On Line) (Byzantine Greek lexicon 10th century AD) and her brothers were Machaon, Podaleirios and Telesphoros. * Aglaea or Ocalea, daughter of Mantineus. She married Abas and had twins: Acrisius and Proetus.Pseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca, 2.2.1 * Aglaea, daughter of Thespius and Megamede. She bore Heracles a son, Antiades.Pseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 2.7.8 * Aglaea, a nymph. She is the mother, by Charopus, of Nireus.Homer, Iliad 2.671Diodorus Siculus, Bibliotheca historica 5.53.2Hyginus, Fabulae 97 * Aglaea, mother of Melampus and Bias by Amythaon.Diodorus Siculus, Bibliotheca historica 4.68.3 == Notes == == References == * Diodorus Siculus, The Library of History translated by Charles Henry Oldfather.
